Learning and AI

INSTRUCTORS

Daniel Rothschild

ABOUT

This class will use recent advances in AI as a foil to examine what we know and what we don’t know about human learning. Readings will be by cognitive scientists, philosophers, journalists, and LLMs.

MECHANICS

The seminar meets Thursdays from 2pm to 5pm in the seminar room of the UCL Philosophy Department, 19 Gordon Square. There is no meeting on 30 May. One extra session will be scheduled later.

The module will be assessed by a 3500-word essay.

Auditors very welcome!

SCHEDULE

25 APRIL: LEARNING IN THEORY AND PRACTICE
Readings

  • Selections from Plato, Locke, Leibniz, Hume, and Fodor on learning.
  • Selections from Stanislas Dehaene How We Learn

Readings available here (ask instructor for password).

2 MAY: MACHINE LEARNING AND DEEP LEARNING

  • Melanie Mitchell, selections from Artificial Intelligence: A Guide for Thinking Humans
  • Cameron Buckner, selections from From Deep Learning to Rational Machines
  • Millière and Buckner A Philosophical Introduction to Language Models – Part I: Continuity With Classic Debates

9 MAY: DO HUMANS LEARN FASTER THAN MACHINES?

16 MAY: LEARNING AND MOTIVATION

23 MAY: ANALOGY AND ABSTRACTION

6 JUNE: LEARNING AS SOCIAL

DATE TBD CULTURAL EVOLUTION AND INTELLIGENCE
